text: In an incident reminiscent of the Shadow Brokers leak that exposed the NSA's hacking tools, someone has now published similar hacking tools belonging to one of Iran's elite cyber-espionage units, known as APT34, Oilrig, or HelixKitten.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: The hacking tools are nowhere near as sophisticated as the NSA tools leaked in 2017, but they are dangerous nevertheless.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: The tools have been leaked since mid-March on a Telegram channel by an individual using the Lab Dookhtegan pseudonym.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Besides hacking tools, Dookhtegan also published what appears to be data from some of APT34's hacked victims, mostly comprising of username and password combos that appear to have been collected through phishing pages.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: ZDNet was previously aware of some of these tools and victim data after this reporter received a tip in mid-March.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: In a Twitter DM, a Twitter user shared some of the same files that were discovered today on Telegram, and we believe that this Twitter user is the Telegram Lab Dookhtegan persona.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: In our Twitter conversation, the leaker claimed to have worked on the group's DNSpionage campaign, but this should be taken with a grain of salt, as the leaker could very well be a member of a foreign intelligence agency trying to hide their real identity while giving more credence to the authenticity of Iran's hacking tools and operations.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Furthermore, ZDNet has also learned that the same Twitter persona had also contacted tens of other reporters and infosec researchers with the same message, in an attempt to promote the leak.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Similarly, the same persona has also posted links to some of these hacking tools on public hacking-focused forums.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: On these forums, he claimed to be selling the hacked files, yet, he never mentioned anything about a price.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Several cyber-security experts have already confirmed the authenticity of these tools.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Chronicle, Alphabet's cyber-security division, confirmed this to ZDNet earlier today.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: In the Telegram channel discovered today, the hacker leaked the source code of six hacking tools, and the content from several active backend panels, where victim data had been collected.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text:
Hacking tools:
- Glimpse (newer version of a PowerShell-based trojan that Palo Alto Networks names BondUpdater)
- PoisonFrog (older version of BondUpdater)
- HyperShell (web shell that Palo Alto Networks calls TwoFace)
- HighShell (another web shell)
- Fox Panel (phishing kit)
- Webmask (DNS tunneling, main tool behind DNSpionage)
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Besides source code for the above tools, Dookhtegan also leaked on the Telegram channel data taken from victims that had been collected in some of APT34's backend command-and-control (C&C) servers.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: In total, according to Chronicle, Dookhtegan leaked data from 66 victims, mainly from countries in the Middle East, but also Africa, East Asia, and Europe.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Data was taken from both government agencies, but also from private companies.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: The two biggest companies named on the Telegram channel are Etihad Airways and Emirates National Oil.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: A list of the victims (but without company/government agency names) is available here.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Data leaked from each victim varied, ranging from usernames and password combos to internal network servers info and user IPs.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Additionally, Dookhtegan also leaked data about past APT34 operations, listing the IP addresses and domains where the group had hosted web shells in the past, and other operational data.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Besides data on past operations, the leaker also doxxed Iranian Ministry of Intelligence officers, posting phone numbers, images, and names of officers involved with APT34 operations.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: For some officers, Dookhtegan created PDF files containing their names, roles, images, phone numbers, email addresses, and social media profiles.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: It was clear from the detailed doxing packages that the leaker had a bone to pick with the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence officers, to which he referred many times as "cruel," "ruthless," and "criminal.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text:
"
"We have more secret information about the crimes of the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence and its managers and we are determined to continue to expose them," Dookhtegan said in a Telegram message posted last week.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: The leaker also posted screenshots on the Telegram channel alluding to destroying the control panels of APT34 hacking tools and wiping servers clean.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: The data leaked on this Telegram channel is now under analysis by several cyber-security firms, ZDNet was told.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: It has also made its way on other file sharing sites, such as GitHub.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: "It's likely this group will alter their toolset in order to maintain operational status," Brandon Levene, Head of Applied Intelligence at Chronicle, told ZDNet today in an email "There may be some copycat activity derived from the leaked tools, but it is unlikely to see widespread use.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text:
"
This is because the tools aren't sophisticated and aren't top-tier tools like the ones leaked in the Shadow Brokers' NSA leak.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: Nation-state or criminal groups who will reuse these tools will most likely do it as a smoke-screen or false flag, to mask their operations as APT34.
source: Source code of Iranian cyber-espionage tools leaked on Telegram _ ZDNET.html

text: On April 26th, we identified a suspicious email that targeted a government official from Jordan’s foreign ministry.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The email contained a malicious Excel document that drops a new backdoor named Saitama.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text:
Following our investigation, we were able to attribute this attack to the known Iranian Actor APT34.
Also known as OilRig/COBALT GYPSY/IRN2/HELIX KITTEN, APT34 is an Iranian threat group that has targeted Middle Eastern countries and victims worldwide since at least 2014.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The group is known to focus on the financial, governmental, energy, chemical, and telecommunication sectors.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: In this blog post, we describe the attack flow and share details about the Saitama backdoor.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The malicious email was sent to the victim via a Microsoft Outlook account with the subject “Confirmation Receive Document” with an Excel file called “Confirmation Receive Document.xls”.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The sender pretends to be a person from the Government of Jordan by using its coat of arms as a signature.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The Excel attachment contains a macro that performs malicious activities.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The document has an image that tries to convince the victim to enable a macro.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text:
After enabling the macro, the image is replaced with the Jordan government’s the coat of the arms:
The macro has been executed on WorkBook_Open().
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text:
Here are the main functionalities of this macro:
The dropped payload is a small backdoor that is written in .Net.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: It has the following interesting pdb path: E:SaitamaSaitama.AgentobjReleaseSaitama.Agent.pdb.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Saitama backdoor abuses the DNS protocol for its command and control communications.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: This is stealthier than other communication methods, such as HTTP.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Also, the actor cleverly uses techniques such as compression and long random sleep times.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: They employed these tricks to disguise malicious traffic in between legitimate traffic.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Another element that we found interesting about this backdoor is the way that it is implemented.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The whole flow of the program is defined explicitly as a finite-state machine, as shown in the Figure 7.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: In short, the machine will change its state depending on the command sent to every state.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text:
Graphically, the program flow can be seen as this:
It is the initial state of the machine.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: It just accepts the start command that puts the machine into the ALIVE state.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: This state fetches the C&C server, expecting to receive a command from the attackers.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: These servers are generated by using the PRNG algorithm that involves transformations like the Mersenne Twister.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: These transformations will generate subdomains of the hard coded domains in the Config class (Figure 8).
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Figure 9 shows an example of the generated subdomain:
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: This state has two possible next stages.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: If the performed DNS request fails, the next stage is SLEEP.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Otherwise, the next stage is RECEIVE.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: These states put the backdoor in sleep mode.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The amount of time that the program will sleep is determined by the previous stage.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: It is clear that one of the main motivations of the actor is to be as stealthy as possible.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: For example, unsuccessful DNS requests puts the backdoor in sleep mode for a time between 6 and 8 hours!
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text:
There are different sleep times depending on the situations (values are expressed in milliseconds):
There is also a “Second Sleep” state that puts the program on sleep mode a different amount of time.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: This state is used to receiving commands from the C&C servers.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Commands are sent using the IP address field that is returned by the DNS requests.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Further details about the communication protocol are provided later in this report.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: In a nutshell, every DNS request is capable of receiving 4 bytes.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The backdoor will concatenate responses, building buffers in that way.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: These buffers will contain the commands that the backdoor will execute.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: That state will execute commands received from the server.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The backdoor has capabilities like executing remote pre-established commands, custom commands or dropping files.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The communication supports compression, also.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The following figure shows the list of possible commands that can be executed by the backdoor.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: It is pretty shocking to see that even when attackers have the possibility of sending any command, they choose to add that predefined list in the backdoor in Base64 format.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: As we can see, some of them are common reconnaissance snippets, but some of them are not that common.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: In fact, some of the commands contain internal IPsand also internal domain names(like ise-posture.mofagov.gover.local).
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: That shows that this malware was clearly targeted and also indicates that the actor has some previous knowledge about the internal infrastructure of the victim.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The Send state is used to send the results generated by commands to the actor’s server.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: In this case, the name of the subdomain will contain the data.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: As domain names are used to exfiltrate unknown amounts of data, attackers had to split this data in different buffers.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Every buffer is then sent through a different DNS request.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: As it can be seen in the Figure 12, all the required information in order to reconstruct original data is sent to the attackers.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: The size of the buffer is only sent in the first packet.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: There are several indicators that suggest that this campaign has been operated by APT34.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Malwarebytes customers are protected from this attack via our Anti-Exploit layer.
source: APT34 targets Jordan Government using new Saitama backdoor.html

text: Check Point Research discovered evidence of a new campaign by the Iranian threat group APT34 (aka OilRig), against what appears to be a Lebanese target, employing a new backdoor variant we dubbed SideTwist.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Since the 2019 leak of APT34’s tools by an entity named “Lab Dookhtegan”, the threat group has been actively retooling and updating their payload arsenal to try and avoid detection, creating several different malware variants whose ultimate purpose remained the same: to gain the initial foothold on the targeted device.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Starting with the DNSpionage campaign back in 2018, APT34 has been observed targeting individuals through the use of booby-trapped job opportunity documents, delivered directly to the selected targets via LinkedIn messages.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: This activity continued through 2019 with the HardPass operation, in which the LinkedIn platform was used in the same manner.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: In this latest campaign from January, a document submitted to VirusTotal from Lebanon (a common target for APT34), also depicts such a job opportunity document, although in this case we were unable to confirm the initial delivery mechanism to the target.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: In the following article we analyze the latest infection chain used by the attackers and deep dive into the new malware variant.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Our analysis began with a malicious Microsoft Word document named Job-Details.doc (md5: 6615c410b8d7411ed14946635947325e).
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The decoy document clearly tries to appear like a benign document, offering various positions in the Ntiva IT consulting company – a company based in Virginia, US.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
However, once the user activates the embedded malicious macros, the full infection flow is triggered:
Macros used by APT34’s job opportunity campaigns have evolved through the years, but also managed to keep their own distinctive style and purpose:
In the macros function call graph above, we can see that from the Document_Open and the Document_Close functions, there are multiple calls to the DnsQuery external function.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: APT34 is notorious for its heavy use of DNS tunneling through many of their different tools, and this time this feature also made its way into the initial macros stage.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Once the macros are executed, DNS requests are used to beacon back to the attacker, and inform them of the current stage of the execution, as well as to deliver some victim identifiable information.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: In this step, the attacker is using the publicly available requestbin.net DNS tunneling service, in order to get updates about the macros infection progress.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: This way the attacker-owned infrastructure would not be exposed, in case a sandbox would not be able to fully “detonate” the document.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Below is a demonstration of the information the attacker would see on the requesbin.net website, when a victim executes the malicious macros from a system with the following environment:
The encoded data is derived from the PC information, in the following manner:
The backdoor in this stage, is a variant we haven’t seen before in previous APT34 operations, but provides functionality which is simple and similar to other C based backdoors utilized by the group: DNSpionage and TONEDEAF and TONEDEAF2.0.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The functionality of the backdoor includes download, upload and shell command execution.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: In this infection chain the persistence is actually established by the 1st stage macros, and the 2nd stage payload does not have any persistence mechanism of its own.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Persistence is achieved in the 1st stage, when the schedule task is registered.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
The scheduled task named SystemFailureReporter will execute the 2nd stage payload every 5 minutes:
The backdoor is very dependent on this persistence mechanism, as every time it would launch, it would only execute a single command provided from the C&C server and immediately shut down, until it is launched again by the scheduled task.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The backdoor starts by collecting basic information about the victim’s machine and calculating a 4-byte long victim identifier, based on the user-name, computer-name and the domain name of the target environment.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: This identifier will be used in the follow-up C&C communication.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
Next the malware will verify that the update.xml file that was supposed to be created in the 1st stage of the infection does indeed exists, and if not, it will terminate itself – printing the following text to the debugging output using the OutputDebugString function:
“Please install visual studio 2017 and try again”
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: As the purpose of this function is to print debugging information, only during the debugging process of an application, the text will not be visible to the regular user.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The backdoor’s communication with the C&C server (sarmsoftware[.]com) is HTTP based on port 443 with port 80 as fallback.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The backdoor uses two different techniques for its outgoing and incoming communications with the C&C server, though in both cases the same encryption algorithm is utilized (see more on encryption below).
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The backdoor contacts the C&C server in the following URL using a GET request:
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
The response to this request is hidden in the source code of following Flickr lookalike page:
The response is returned to the backdoor within the HTML code, in the following format:
After this base64 string is decoded and decrypted, the plain-text content is in the following pipe-separated format:
After the backdoor has executed an arbitrary command on the victim’s machine, it returns the result of the executed command to the C&C server, to the same URL as before, but in a POST request instead of a GET:
The format of the POST body is a simple JSON, based on the command number provided from the C&C server and the encrypted result of the command execution:
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: As the basis for the encrypted communication, the attackers utilize the Mersenne Twister pseudorandom number generator.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The 4 first bytes of each encrypted message is the seed for the Mersenne Twister, to be used for the decryption of the rest of the message.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text:
The encrypted Base64 communication can be decrypted using the following Python snippet:
Both the malicious macros, the backdoor, the targeting, and the techniques used in this operation – all align with previously reported campaigns attributed to APT34.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Besides the fact that like in previous APT34 operations, once again we see job opportunity documents being used to encourage the victim to enable macros, there are technical similarities as well.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: APT34’s backdoors DNSpionage and TONEDEAF are known to receive commands from the servers by searching for specific pattern hidden inside the HTML content of a legitimate looking website.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: In our case the attackers utilized a Flickr lookalike page, while in previous campaigns GitHub, Wikipedia, and Microsoft lookalikes were used.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: While analyzing the above campaign, this and additional APT34 related documents were uploaded to VirusTotal and noted by malware researchers on Twitter.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: These documents utilized the very same requestbin.net DNS tunneling service in the initial macros and delivered another of the group’s signature tools: a variant of the .NET based backdoor named Karkoff, which utilized internet facing exchange servers as a communication method with the attackers.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The newly found artifacts emphasize the extent of the ongoing APT34’s offensive operations against targets in the Middle East, and especially in Lebanon:
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: The Karkoff implant (MD5: ab25014c3d6f77ec5880c8f9728be968) included credentials for an exchange server belonging to the Lebanese Government (mail.army.gov[.]lb), which might be an indication of a long running compromise of their network.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Iran backed APT34 shows no sign of slowing down, further pushing its political agenda in the middle-east, with an ongoing focus on Lebanon – using offensive cyber operations.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: While maintaining its modus operandi and reusing old techniques, as reviewed above, the group continues to create new and updated tools to minimize the possible detection of their tools by security vendors.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: In this publication we analyzed the newest backdoor variant deployed by the group’s ongoing job opportunities campaigns, which includes malicious documents with job offers – a technique they have successfully employed since at least 2018.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

text: Check Point Sandblast protects against this APT attack, and prevents it from the very first steps.
source: Iran’s APT34 Returns with an Updated Arsenal - Check Point Research.html

Our researchers Paul Litvak and Michael Kajilolti have discovered a new campaign conducted by APT34 employing an updated toolset.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Based on uncovered phishing documents, we believe this Iranian actor is targeting Westat employees, or United States organizations hiring Westat services.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Westat is a United States-based company that “provides research services to agencies of the U.S. Government, as well as businesses, foundations, and state and local governments”.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: One example of the services Westat offers is a survey for federal workers, which leads us to believe this attack may target Westat customers.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Official Westat response: “Westat understands that in their effort to identify threats and malware, Intezer has identified a malicious file that uses the Westat name and logo.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: This file was not created by, hosted by, or sent from Westat, and is likely the result of a bad actor stealing the Westat brand name and logo.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Our cybersecurity team is working with Intezer and others to fully understand the nature of this report.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: We will continue to monitor the situation and respond accordingly.”
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: APT34 (also known as OilRig or Helix Kitten) is a cluster of Iranian government-backed cyber espionage activities that has been active since 2014.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The group is known to target various international organizations, mainly in the Middle East.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Among their targeted industries are government agencies, financial services, energy and utilities, telecommunications, and oil and gas.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: More light was shed on this group in April 2019 as leaks emerged from a mysterious individual with the pseudonym “Lab Dookhtegan”.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: This individual exposed data belonging to victims of this group, together with source code of hacking tools and data about previous APT34 operations; including IP addresses and domains where the group hosted web shells related to past operations.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Most recently, FireEye exposed a spear-phishing operation conducted by APT34, which enabled us to connect this operation to this Iranian actor due to similarities in the techniques and tools employed in both campaigns.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: In late January 2020, we discovered a file named survey.xls that was designed to look like an employee satisfaction survey tailored to either Westat employees or Westat customers.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: At first the spreadsheet appeared to be blank.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Only once the victim enables macros, the survey is displayed to the user and the malicious VBA code begins to execute.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The embedded VBA code unpacks a zip file into a temporary folder, extracts a “Client update.exe” executable file and installs it to “C:Users<User>valsClient update.exe”.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: “Client update.exe” is actually a highly modified version of the TONEDEAF malware, which we named TONEDEAF 2.0.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Finally, the crtt function creates a scheduled task “CheckUpdate” that runs the unpacked executable five minutes after being infected by it, as well as on future log-ons.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
Both the extracted VBA code and the functionality of the code look similar to the one analyzed in the FireEye report:
APT34 VBA Code from the FireEye Report
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: In addition, we found a similar document labelled as “Employee satisfaction survey.xls” containing the same survey as the previous document.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: However, it’s important to highlight that the code page field of this document is Arabic as can be seen when examining its file metadata, denoting the preferred language installed on the document author’s version of Microsoft Excel:
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: At first glance, “Client update.exe” seems like a completely new backdoor malware.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: However, further examination reveals it’s most likely a highly modified version of the previously seen TONEDEAF backdoor.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: TONEDEAF is a backdoor that communicates with its Command and Control server via HTTP in order to receive and execute commands.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: It was mentioned in FireEye’s recent report about an ongoing APT34 operation, as one of the group’s custom tools.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: We have named the new variant TONEDEAF 2.0.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: TONEDEAF 2.0 is an advanced version of TONEDEAF, serving the same purpose as the original, but with a revamped C2 communication protocol and a substantially modified code base.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: In contrast to the original TONEDEAF, TONEDEAF 2.0 contains solely arbitrary shell execution capabilities, and doesn’t support any predefined commands.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: It’s also more stealthy and contains new tricks such as dynamic importing, string decoding, and a victim deception method.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Upon execution the backdoor checks whether it was executed with “…” as an argument, which is the way it’s configured to execute by the scheduled task, as part of the proper infection chain.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: In the case it’s executed without the correct argument, such as by launching it via a double click, it will display a blank GUI Window to the user.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: This is most likely intended to serve as a deception method, to make the malware appear like a legitimate (alibiet broken) application titled “Bee”.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: TONEDEAF 2.0 also attempts to be more stealthy than its predecessor by hiding many of the interesting API imports it uses.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The names of these APIs, and the DLLs that contain them, are stored as encoded strings and are decoded and resolved on demand during runtime.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The backdoor uses HTTP for C2 communication, with a custom encoding and handshake mechanisms.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Messages sent by the backdoor always contain the HTTP query parameter “?ser=<6 digits>” as an identifier.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The first three digits are the <server_id> and the last three are the <client_id>.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
The backdoor will use one of the following two messages:
1.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: GET /dow?ser=<server_id><client_id>  – request message, used to obtain commands to execute from the server.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html
Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: POST /upl?ser==<server_id><client_id>  – reply to command message, used to send the executed command’s output to the server.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Before performing the first request, the malware will generate the <client_id> derived from the environment variables %HOMEPATH% and %COMPUTERNAME% using a custom formula.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: It will then send an initial GET message to the C2 using that ID.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: One odd element about the communication is the usage of a Windows Phone User-Agent  value in the HTTP message.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: During our analysis the C2 was alive but continuously replied with a 403 Forbidden HTTP error code to our requests.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: It’s possible that the C2 is filtering the targets since this backdoor is part of a targeted operation and our client_id parameter does not match that of one of the intended victims.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Should the C2 accept the ID, it will reply with an encoded message that contains the <server_id> and the command the backdoor needs to execute.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The malware extracts the command by looking for an HTTP div element in the response with a special class name.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The malware will then execute the command by prepending it with “cmd U c” and will send the output of the command back to the C2 using the POST reply message (2).
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
When entering the C2 via a browser, the site tries to imitate https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/, although it fails to display it properly due to a misconfiguration with the CSS, as can be seen in the console:
We have also observed that an SSL certificate has been recently generated that matches the domain of the C2.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
SSL Certificate for the C2 Domain that was Issued One Month Ago
These findings might indicate that the attackers are in the process of transitioning into HTTPS for C2 communication, in an attempt to improve their OPSEC capabilities and avoid detection.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: With all of the changes and new additions, there are still enough similarities that link TONEDEAF 2.0 to the original.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: While the code is mostly modified, the general flow and functionality are similar.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The C2 communication is different but still has similarities to its predecessor, such as the usage of three digit identifiers for both the victim and the server.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: However, most notably there are several places in the code where the similarity is most clear.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: One such place is a function that exists in both variants, which oddly enough creates a notification icon in the Windows status bar.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The only notable changes are the usage of dynamic API resolution and the shortening of the notification message from “Updating” to “up”.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Another instance is the code that sets the working directory of the program.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text:
It appears in different stages for each variant, but is identical:
We were unable to download further modules, however, we believe this operation also includes the usage of a VALUEVAULT implant.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: VALUEVAULT is a browser credential theft tool built in Golang, discovered by FireEye in the aforementioned APT34 operation analysis.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: We found the survey.xls file uploaded to VirusTotal with a VALUEVAULT instance and a TONEDEAF 2.0 instance, uploaded from Lebanon by the same user, only a few minutes apart.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: This may indicate that these malware were delivered together as part of the same attack.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: This VALUEVAULT takes a more minimalistic approach than its predecessor.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Many functionalities and strings were stripped from the new binary in order to lower its noise.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Only Chrome password dumping is now supported, although interestingly the use of the file “fsociety.dat” as a password data store under the “AppData\Roaming” directory stayed the same.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Furthermore, VALUEVAULT 2.0 is a 64-bit binary as opposed to VALUEVAULT 1.0 which is a 32-bit binary.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: These relatively minor changes were enough to create a fully undetected implant.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The last APT34 operation was exposed only a few months ago by FireEye, and judging by our current findings we can confidently state that the group has since evolved its operations.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The technical analysis of the new malware variants reveals this Iranian government-backed group has invested substantial efforts into upgrading its toolset in an attempt to evade future detection.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: The binary code from these new malware samples are now indexed in our Genetic Malware Analysis platform, Intezer Analyze.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: We encourage you to use our free community edition to detect and classify threats that share code with APT34 malware.
source: Iranian Campaign Tailored to US Companies Uses Updated Toolset - Intezer.html

text: Less than a week after Microsoft issued a patch for CVE-2017-11882 on Nov. 14, 2017, FireEye observed an attacker using an exploit for the Microsoft Office vulnerability to target a government organization in the Middle East.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We assess this activity was carried out by a suspected Iranian cyber espionage threat group, whom we refer to as APT34, using a custom PowerShell backdoor to achieve its objectives.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We believe APT34 is involved in a long-term cyber espionage operation largely focused on reconnaissance efforts to benefit Iranian nation-state interests and has been operational since at least 2014.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: This threat group has conducted broad targeting across a variety of industries, including financial, government, energy, chemical, and telecommunications, and has largely focused its operations within the Middle East.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We assess that APT34 works on behalf of the Iranian government based on infrastructure details that contain references to Iran, use of Iranian infrastructure, and targeting that aligns with nation-state interests.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: APT34 uses a mix of public and non-public tools, often conducting spear phishing operations using compromised accounts, sometimes coupled with social engineering tactics.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: In May 2016, we published a blog detailing a spear phishing campaign targeting banks in the Middle East region that used macro-enabled attachments to distribute POWBAT malware.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We now attribute that campaign to APT34.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: In July 2017, we observed APT34 targeting a Middle East organization using a PowerShell-based backdoor that we call POWRUNER and a downloader with domain generation algorithm functionality that we call BONDUPDATER, based on strings within the malware.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The backdoor was delivered via a malicious .rtf file that exploited CVE-2017-0199.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: In this latest campaign, APT34 leveraged the recent Microsoft Office vulnerability CVE-2017-11882 to deploy POWRUNER and BONDUPDATER.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The full report on APT34 is available to our MySIGHT customer community.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: APT34 loosely aligns with public reporting related to the group "OilRig".
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: As individual organizations may track adversaries using varied data sets, it is possible that our classifications of activity may not wholly align.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: CVE-2017-11882 affects several versions of Microsoft Office and, when exploited, allows a remote user to run arbitrary code in the context of the current user as a result of improperly handling objects in memory.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The vulnerability was patched by Microsoft on Nov. 14, 2017.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: A full proof of concept (POC) was publicly released a week later by the reporter of the vulnerability.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The vulnerability exists in the old Equation Editor (EQNEDT32.EXE), a component of Microsoft Office that is used to insert and evaluate mathematical formulas.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The Equation Editor is embedded in Office documents using object linking and embedding (OLE) technology.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: It is created as a separate process instead of child process of Office applications.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: If a crafted formula is passed to the Equation Editor, it does not check the data length properly while copying the data, which results in stack memory corruption.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: As the EQNEDT32.exe is compiled using an older compiler and does not support address space layout randomization (ASLR), a technique that guards against the exploitation of memory corruption vulnerabilities, the attacker can easily alter the flow of program execution.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: APT34 sent a malicious .rtf file (MD5: a0e6933f4e0497269620f44a083b2ed4) as an attachment in a malicious spear phishing email sent to the victim organization.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The malicious file exploits CVE-2017-11882, which corrupts the memory on the stack and then proceeds to push the malicious data to the stack.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The malware then overwrites the function address with the address of an existing instruction from EQNEDT32.EXE.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The overwritten instruction (displayed in Figure 1) is used to call the “WinExec” function from kernel32.dll, as depicted in the instruction at 00430c12, which calls the “WinExec” function.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: After exploitation, the ‘WinExec’ function is successfully called to create a child process, “mshta.exe”, in the context of current logged on user.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The process “mshta.exe” downloads a malicious script from hxxp://mumbai-m[.]site/b.txt and executes it, as seen in Figure 2.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The malicious script goes through a series of steps to successfully execute and ultimately establish a connection to the command and control (C2) server.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The full sequence of events starting with the exploit document is illustrated in Figure 3.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 4 contains an excerpt of the v.vbs script pertaining to the Execution Workflow section.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: After successful execution of the steps mentioned in the Execution Workflow section, the Task Scheduler will launch GoogleUpdateschecker.vbs
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: every minute, which in turn executes the dUpdateCheckers.ps1 and hUpdateCheckers.ps1 scripts.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: These PowerShell scripts are final stage payloads – they include a downloader with domain generation algorithm (DGA) functionality and the backdoor component, which connect to the C2 server to receive commands and perform additional malicious activities.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The backdoor component, POWRUNER, is a PowerShell script that sends and receives commands to and from the C2 server.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: POWRUNER is executed every minute by the Task Scheduler.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 5 contains an excerpt of the POWRUNER backdoor.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: POWRUNER begins by sending a random GET request to the C2 server and waits for a response.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The server will respond with either “not_now” or a random 11-digit number.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: If the response is a random number, POWRUNER will send another random GET request to the server and store the response in a string.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: POWRUNER will then check the last digit of the stored random number response, interpret the value as a command, and perform an action based on that command.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The command values and the associated actions are described in Table 1.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text:
Server response string contains batch commands
Execute batch commands and send results back to server
Server response string is a file path
Check for file path and upload (PUT) the file to server
Server response string is a file path
Check for file path and download (GET) the file
After successfully executing the command, POWRUNER sends the results back to the C2 server and stops execution.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The C2 server can also send a PowerShell command to capture and store a screenshot of a victim’s system.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: POWRUNER will send the captured screenshot image file to the C2 server if the “fileupload” command is issued.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 6 shows the PowerShell “Get-Screenshot” function sent by the C2 server.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: One of the recent advancements by APT34 is the use of DGA to generate subdomains.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text:
The BONDUPDATER script, which was named based on the hard-coded string “B007”, uses a custom DGA algorithm to generate subdomains for communication with the C2 server.
Figure 7 provides a breakdown of how an example domain (456341921300006B0C8B2CE9C9B007.mumbai-m[.]site) is generated using BONDUPDATER’s custom DGA.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text:
BONDUPDATER will attempt to resolve the resulting DGA domain and will take the following actions based on the IP address resolution:
File contains batch commands, it executes the batch commands
Rename the temporary file as .ps1 extension
Rename the temporary file as .vbs extension
Figure 8 is a screenshot of BONDUPDATER’s DGA implementation.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text:
Some examples of the generated subdomains observed at time of execution include:
Figure 9 shows example network communications between a POWRUNER backdoor client and server.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: In the example, the POWRUNER client sends a random GET request to the C2 server and the C2 server sends the random number (99999999990) as a response.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: As the response is a random number that ends with ‘0’, POWRUNER sends another random GET request to receive  an additional command string.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The C2 server sends back Base64 encoded response.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: If the server had sent the string “not_now” as response, as shown in Figure 10, POWRUNER would have ceased any further requests and terminated its execution.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: POWRUNER may also receive batch commands from the C2 server to collect host information from the system.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: This may include information about the currently logged in user, the hostname, network configuration data, active connections, process information, local and domain administrator accounts, an enumeration of user directories, and other data.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: An example batch command is provided in Figure 11.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: APT34 has used POWRUNER and BONDUPDATER to target Middle East organizations as early as July 2017.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: In July 2017, a FireEye Web MPS appliance detected and blocked a request to retrieve and install an APT34 POWRUNER / BONDUPDATER downloader file.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: During the same month, FireEye observed APT34 target a separate Middle East organization using a malicious .rtf file (MD5: 63D66D99E46FB93676A4F475A65566D8) that exploited CVE-2017-0199.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text:
This file issued a GET request to download a malicious file from:
As shown in Figure 12, the script within the dupatechecker.doc file attempts to download another file named dupatechecker.exe from the same server.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The file also contains a comment by the malware author that appears to be an apparent taunt to security researchers.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The dupatechecker.exe file (MD5: C9F16F0BE8C77F0170B9B6CE876ED7FB) drops both BONDUPDATER and POWRUNER.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: These files connect to proxychecker[.]pro for C2.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: Recent activity by APT34 demonstrates that they are capable group with potential access to their own development resources.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: During the past few months, APT34 has been able to quickly incorporate exploits for at least two publicly vulnerabilities (CVE-2017-0199 and CVE-2017-11882) to target organizations in the Middle East.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We assess that APT34’s efforts to continuously update their malware, including the incorporation of DGA for C2, demonstrate the group’s commitment to pursing strategies to deter detection.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: We expect APT34 will continue to evolve their malware and tactics as they continue to pursue access to entities in the Middle East region.
source: New Targeted Attack in the Middle East by APT34, a Suspected Iranian Threat Group, Using CVE-2017-11882 Exploit _ Mandiant.html

text: The three C2 domains used by this malware seem to have a similar naming convention as the other domains found on this IP address.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The amount of effort put into developing this attack is much higher than the average run-of-the-mill phishing/spam campaign, putting it on the level of an APT attack.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: From the start, the attackers posed as a valid user and kept the email short without any grammatical errors.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: They then proceeded to use an Excel macro with advanced techniques, including possible anti-analysis techniques with the mouse check and the sheet visibility switch.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Furthermore, while state programming is rarely used in malware, in this attack, both the Excel macro and the malware make use of it.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: After checking in, the malware sleeps for 6-8 hours.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: One likely reason might be that the threat actors expected the diplomat to open the spearphishing email in the morning and then leave at the end of the day.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: At that point, the attackers would be free to operate.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: While using DNS tunneling for C2 communications is nothing new, it is rarely seen in practice.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Their backdoor also supports a long list of very specific commands.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: From the looks of things, the threat actors did their homework since their backdoor commands clearly demonstrate they already had prior knowledge of their target’s internal network infrastructure.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: This indicates that the threat actors most likely gained limited access somewhere else before this spearphishing attempt was made.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Looking at their C2 servers, two out of the three seem to be tightly controlled.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: They were only brought up at specific times.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: The third C2 server has been lumped in with various other domains to further complicate proper attribution.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: Given all the breadcrumbs, this campaign looks to be another one launched by APT34.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html

text: They have demonstrated they possess the resources necessary to infiltrate a government network and are no strangers to using more advanced techniques.
source: Please Confirm You Received Our APT _ FortiGuard Labs.html
